We have never wished that the United States commit troops to this fight.
When I moved to the United States, I moved to Arkansas.

I understand.

So then the question becomes what is the end game?
What comes after?
One of the issues within the United States has been whom to support, which rebel group to support, because some of the most effective opposition groups have been Islamist groups.
And a lot of people within the United States object to supporting these groups.
Are their constituencies within Syria that could effectively form a democratic movement?
Sure.
First, I want to tell you in terms of ISIS, that is completely alien and non-Syrian.
And so the Syrian people have fought against ISIS way more than the regime ever has and vice versa.

In terms of Islamist groups, things like al-Nusra, whenever there is even a lull in firing, the next day we see protests not against the regime but against Jabhat al-Nusra and other Islamist groups that are in the area.

But whenever we are not supporting and whenever other countries with different agendas are supporting with their own conditions, then people grow their beard to the length of their funder.
